com.dp16.eventbroker

Class EventBroker

  • java.lang.Object
    • com.dp16.eventbroker.EventBroker
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    java.lang.Runnable

    public final class EventBroker
extends java.lang.Object
implements java.lang.Runnable
    Threadsafe Event broker. Listeners must implement EventListener. Publishers must implement EventPublisher. Publishers can also extend the EventPublisherClass which offers the EventPublisherClass.publishEvent(String, Object) convenience method. The event type can be any string.

    Normally a listener registers for events by implementing EventListener and calling addEventListener(String, EventListener, int) with this as second argument. A listener can stop receiving events by calling removeEventListener(String, EventListener) with this as last argument.
    A publisher implements EventPublisher and calls addEvent(String, Object, EventPublisher) with this as the last argument. Alternatively a publisher extends EventPublisherClass and calls EventPublisherClass.publishEvent(String, Object).
    The start() and stop() methods are usually called from the setup and teardown of the application respectively.

    A few examples can be found in the unit tests in the EventBrokerUnitTests.java file.
    See Also:
    EventListener, EventPublisher, Created by Nick on 25-2-2017.

    • Method Detail

      • getInstance

        public static EventBroker getInstance()
        Singleton access method.
        Returns:
        The singleton instance of this class.

      • start

        public void start()
        Starts the event broker. Does nothing if called on a running event broker.

      • stop

        public void stop()
        Stops the event broker. No new events are accepted after this method is called. Events already in the broker are still processed. This deletes all internal state. A call to start() after this method returns will behave the same as the first call to start(). Important: this method does not return until the event broker has fully stopped. This may take a considerable amount of time if the event queue has a lot of items.

      • addEventListener

        public int addEventListener(java.lang.String type,
                            EventListener listener)
        Registers an EventListener for one event type. Does nothing if the EventListener already listens for the given event type. This method is equivalent to addEventListener(String, EventListener, int).
        Parameters:
        type - Event type to listen to.
        listener - EventListener to be registered.
        Returns:
        1 when listener is added, -1 when listener is not added

      • addEventListener

        public int addEventListener(java.util.Collection<java.lang.String> types,
                            EventListener listener)
        Registers an EventListener for a collection of event types. Does nothing if the EventListener already listens for the given event type. This method is equivalent to addEventListener(Collection, EventListener, int) }
        Parameters:
        types - Event type to listen to.
        listener - EventListener to be registered.
        Returns:
        1 when the listener is added for all types, -x if the listener could not be added for all types (where x is the amount of types that failed)

      • addEventListener

        public int addEventListener(java.lang.String type,
                            EventListener listener,
                            int interval)
        Registers an EventListener for an event type. An event will only be delivered when at least 'interval' ms have passed since the last delivered event. Any event published during the interval will be lost for this listener.
        If a new interval is required, the listener has to be removed first (see removeEventListener(String, EventListener)).
        Parameters:
        type - Event type to listen to
        listener - EventListener to be registered
        interval - Minimum amount of milliseconds (ms) in between updates
        Returns:
        1 when listener is added, -1 when listener is not added

      • addEventListener

        public int addEventListener(java.util.Collection<java.lang.String> types,
                            EventListener listener,
                            int interval)
        Registers an EventListener for a collection of types. An event will only be delivered when at least 'interval' ms have passed since the last delivered event. Any event published during the interval will be lost for this listener.
        If a new interval is required, the listener has to be removed first (see removeEventListener(String, EventListener)).
        Parameters:
        types - Event type to listen to
        listener - EventListener to be registered
        interval - Minimum amount of milliseconds in between updates
        Returns:
        1 when the listener is added for all types, -x if the listener could not be added for all types (where x is the amount of types that failed)

      • removeEventListener

        public int removeEventListener(java.lang.String type,
                               EventListener listener)
        Unregisters the EventListener for one event type. Potential other event types are not affected. Does nothing if the EventListener is not registered for the event type.
        Parameters:
        type - Event type to unregister from.
        listener - EventListener to be unregistered.
        Returns:
        1 when listener is removed, -1 when listener is not removed

      • removeEventListener

        public int removeEventListener(EventListener listener)
        Unregisters the EventListener for all event types. Calls method above for every type of event. Does nothing if the EventListener is not registered.
        Parameters:
        listener - EventListener to be unregistered.
        Returns:
        number of times EventListener is removed, -1 if not removed

      • getAmountOfListeners

        public int getAmountOfListeners()
        For testing purposes. Listeners that listen for multiple events are only counted once.
        Returns:
        Amount of listeners that listen for a specified event type.

      • addEvent

        public void addEvent(java.lang.String eventType,
                     java.lang.Object message,
                     EventPublisher source)
        Publishes an event to the event broker.
        Parameters:
        eventType - This event type can be any String.
        message - Message to send to all listeners.
        source - The EventPublisher that generated the event.

      • run

        public void run()
        Thread code. Takes an item from the queue to process in each iteration. Waits when the queue is empty. Stops when the queue is empty and stopSignalReceived is set
        Specified by:
        run in interface java.lang.Runnable
